awd_titl_txt: EAGER:   Sensing storm surge: A citizen science approach to measuring storm surge-estuarine interaction in three Maine communities
awd_abstract_narration:
1644691 
Huguenard, Kimberly
    
This award is under NSF's topic of Public Participation in Scientific Research. Facing escalating costs to infrastructure and the local economy, U.S. coastal communities are increasingly exploring protection measures to reduce storm surge risk. To date, researchers have relied on models to represent idealized scenarios of storm surge behavior; however, without observations to capture how storm surge behaves inside an estuary, actual effects remain a mystery. To explore this question, this project pursues three interconnected objectives: (1) to develop an improved understanding of storm surge behavior in three Maine estuaries with varying physical properties; (2) to engage local residents in data gathering, involving training; and (3) to evaluate the citizen science component by establishing the reliability of the physical data and by measuring citizen scientists' engagement in climate change-related issues. 

The first objective will be achieved by deploying a network of pressure sensors maintained by local citizen scientists. Statistical analyses will quantify storm surge amplitude and phase propagation properties as it interacts with varying channel geometries, geomorphology, river discharge, and estuary alignments. To achieve the second objective, individuals will be assigned to one of four groups that vary by contributory or co-created approach to citizen science -- specifically, whether in-person training is provided, and whether a co-designed, dialogue-based activity occurs. The third objective will be achieved in two parts, by first evaluating the outcomes of citizen science participation, and second, by assessing the reliability of physical data. A pre- and post- project survey, in addition to in-depth interviews, will evaluate cognitive, affective, and behavioral indicators of engagement. Data reliability will be quantified using cross correlation between citizen science data and duplicate station data maintained by an expert scientist. Between-group comparisons will allow for testing of whether differences in citizen science approaches are associated with data accuracy.

por.por_cntn:
The Sensing Storm Surge project is a collaborative network of University of Maine scientists and citizen scientists to measure storm surge behavior in three estuaries in Maine: the Penobscot River, the Bagaduce River, and Bass Harbor/Southwest Harbor. This interdisciplinary research, which was comprised of social and physical science aspects, featured several interconnected objectives. The first was to develop an improved understanding of storm surge behavior in estuaries with varying physical properties. The second objective was to use a quasi-experimental design to engage local residents in data gathering and varying trainings.

The overarching physical science finding is that the morphology of a system and the storm path is very important for storm surge behavior. Along Maine's coast, storms tracking over land tend to bring stronger winds from the south, which lead to significant storm surges at our more landward locations. Storms that tracked over the sea contained more significant pressure surge and create larger storm surge at our coastal locations. We identified variations in storm surge behavior between storm events of different wind and pressure fields. The most significant finding was that storm surge, tides and river flow can interact with each other, which contributes significantly to overall flooding. While there is a body of literature that details how the principal tide interacts with storm surge, there is a dearth of studies that investigate how storm surge can enhance higher frequency tides to exacerbate total water levels. To our knowledge, this is the first study that shows that tide-surge-river interaction can contribute more to flooding than wind and pressure-driven surge. 

The National Weather Service's Extra-Tropical Storm Surge (ETSS) model does not capture higher frequency tide-surge-river interaction and thus can markedly underestimate the magnitude and timing of inland storm surge flooding. Figure 1 compares the storm surge predicted by the Extra-Tropical Storm Surge (ETSS) model with our observations at the mouth (Rockland), middle (Castine) and head (Bangor) of the Penobscot River. Not only does this figure highlight the increase in tide-surge-river interaction up the river, but it also emphasizes that the timing of flooding is predicted to occur earlier than what was observed, in addition to under predicting the total storm surge level by 1.6 m. This finding draws the need for more research into high frequency tide-surge-river interaction in storm surge predictions.

The principal social science finding highlighted various challenges specific to this project, and more generally associated with citizen science endeavors. Along these lines, on a conceptual level, we found that citizen scientists' and project facilitators' understandings of a 'co-created' project impacted the type of project that, in turn, materialized. Although citizen scientists were on the front lines of the data collecting process -securing monthly water level measurements from the field, for instance- they had limited encounters with the broader scientific process. While we provided the option to upload photos of their field sites and pose questions on the internal data platform- both of which could allow citizen scientists to reflect on their experiences- the platform severely limited the citizen scientists' ability to engage more substantively with the process and the data. Not only were the website prompts developed solely by the researchers (without input from the citizen scientists), but the citizen scientists' responses were not available to project facilitators until several months into the project, thus limiting the opportunity for dialogue. Along these lines, many citizen scientists expressed wanting an extended relationship with project facilitators, including opportunities to continue discussing project goals, as well as generally being kept apprised of (and included in) project decisions.

The impacts of the Sensing Storm Surge project have been disseminated through a number of avenues. Preliminary findings were presented to local stakeholders in the three science cafes held in July 2018. Water level data were shared with the National Weather Service (NWS). Processed storm surge data are now publically available for visualization and download on the updated project website (see http://sensingstormsurgetest.acg.maine.edu/dashboard/data). A technical report has been disseminated to all stakeholders (project participants, science cafe participants, elected officials, town managers, etc.) detailing the principal findings of the project. Additionally, this project provided the opportunity to engage roughly 30 students at Camden Hills Regional High School and the Watershed School in Rockport and Camden, ME, respectively. These students are continuing data collection in Rockport and Camden and received a classroom talk by the project's two graduate students about the scientific process, the project, why it is important, and what the data means, which they can collect and view. Students then got hands-on experience in the field working with the equipment themselves.
